[Glossary](/wiki/Glossary_of_Hinduism_terms) - [Outline](/wiki/Outline_of_Hinduism) - Hinduism portal - v - t - e **Dipavali** ([IAST](/wiki/IAST): *Dīpāvalī*),[a] commonly known as **Diwali** (/dɪˈwɑːliː/), is the [Hindu festival](/wiki/Hindu_festival) of lights, with variations celebrated in other [Indian religions](/wiki/Indian_religions) such as [Jainism](/wiki/Jainism) and [Sikhism](/wiki/Sikhism).[b] It symbolises the spiritual victory of *[Dharma](/wiki/Dharma)* over *[Adharma](/wiki/Adharma)*, light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance.[*page needed*] Diwali is celebrated during the [Hindu lunisolar](/wiki/Hindu_calendar) months of [Ashvin](/wiki/Ashvin_(month)) (according to the [amanta](/wiki/Hindu_calendar#amanta) tradition) and [Kārtika](/wiki/Kartika_(month)) – between around mid-October and mid-November. The celebrations generally last five or six days. Diwali is connected to various religious events, deities and personalities, such as being the day [Rama](/wiki/Rama) returned to his [kingdom](/wiki/Kosala) in [Ayodhya](/wiki/Ayodhya_(Ramayana)) with his wife [Sita](/wiki/Sita) and his brother [Lakshmana](/wiki/Lakshmana) after defeating the demon king [Ravana](/wiki/Ravana). It is also widely associated with [Lakshmi](/wiki/Lakshmi), the goddess of prosperity, and [Ganesha](/wiki/Ganesha), the god of wisdom and the remover of obstacles. Other regional traditions connect the holiday to [Vishnu](/wiki/Vishnu), [Krishna](/wiki/Krishna), [Durga](/wiki/Durga), [Shiva](/wiki/Shiva), [Kali](/wiki/Kali), [Hanuman](/wiki/Hanuman), [Kubera](/wiki/Kubera), [Yama](/wiki/Yama), [Yami](/wiki/Yami), [Dhanvantari](/wiki/Dhanvantari), or [Vishvakarman](/wiki/Vishvakarman). Primarily a [Hindu](/wiki/Hindus) festival, variations of Diwali are also celebrated by adherents of other faiths. The [Jains](/wiki/Jainism) observe their [own Diwali](/wiki/Diwali_(Jainism)) which marks the final liberation of [Mahavira](/wiki/Mahavira). The [Sikhs](/wiki/Sikhism) celebrate [Bandi Chhor Divas](/wiki/Bandi_Chhor_Divas) to mark the release of [Guru Hargobind](/wiki/Guru_Hargobind) from a [Mughal](/wiki/Mughal_Empire) prison. [Newar Buddhists](/wiki/Newar_Buddhism), unlike other [Buddhists](/wiki/Buddhism), celebrate Diwali by worshipping Lakshmi, while the Hindus of [Eastern India](/wiki/Eastern_India) and [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh) generally, celebrate Diwali by worshipping the [goddess Kali](/wiki/Kali). During the festival, the celebrants illuminate their homes, temples and workspaces with [*diyas*](/wiki/Diya_(light)) (oil lamps), candles and lanterns. Hindus, in particular, have a ritual oil bath at dawn on each day of the festival. Diwali is also marked with fireworks as well as the decoration of floors with *[rangoli](/wiki/Rangoli)* designs and other parts of the house with [*jhalars*](/wiki/Jhalar). Food is a major focus with families partaking in feasts and sharing [*mithai*](/wiki/Mithai_(confectionery)). The festival is an annual homecoming and bonding period not only for families, but also for communities and associations, particularly those in urban areas, which will organise activities, events, and gatherings. Many towns organise community parades and fairs with parades or music and dance performances in parks. Some Hindus, Jains, and Sikhs will send Diwali greeting cards to family near and far during the festive season, occasionally with boxes of Indian confectionery. Another aspect of the festival is remembering the ancestors. Diwali is also a major cultural event for the [Hindu](/wiki/Hindus), [Sikh](/wiki/Sikhs), and [Jain](/wiki/Jainism) [diaspora](/wiki/Diaspora). The main day of the festival of Diwali (the day of Lakshmi Puja) is an official holiday in [Fiji](/wiki/Fiji), [Guyana](/wiki/Guyana), [India](/wiki/India), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia),[c] [Mauritius](/wiki/Mauritius), [Myanmar](/wiki/Myanmar), [Nepal](/wiki/Nepal), [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka), [Suriname](/wiki/Suriname), and [Trinidad and Tobago](/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago), and the [US](/wiki/United_States) states of [Connecticut](/wiki/Connecticut), [Pennsylvania](/wiki/Pennsylvania), and [California](/wiki/California). ## Etymology *Diwali*[d] comes from *Dipavali* ([Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit_language): दीपावली, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Sanskrit): *Dīpāvalī*), meaning 'a row or series of lights'. The term is a compound of the Sanskrit words दीप, *dīpa*, 'lamp, light, lantern, candle, that which glows, shines, illuminates or knowledge' and आवलि, *āvali*, 'a row, range, continuous line, series'.[e] ## Dates The five-day celebration is observed every year sometime from the second half of October to the first half of November coinciding with a new moon ([*amāvasyā*](/wiki/Amavasya)) as per the [Hindu lunisolar calendar](/wiki/Hindu_calendar). The festivities begin two days before *[amāvasyā](/wiki/Amavasya)*, on [Dhanteras](/wiki/Dhanteras), and extend two days after, until the second (or 17th) day of the month of Kartik. (According to Indologist Constance Jones, this night ends the lunar month of Ashwin and starts the month of Kartik – but see this note[f] and [Amanta and Purnima systems](/wiki/Hindu_calendar#Amanta_and_Purnima_systems).) The darkest night is the apex of the celebration. The festival climax is on the third day and is called the main Diwali. It is an official holiday in a dozen countries, while the other festive days are regionally observed as either public or optional restricted holidays in India. In Nepal, it is also a multiday festival, although the days and rituals are named differently, with the climax being called the *[Tihar](/wiki/Tihar_(festival))* festival by Hindus and *[Swanti](/wiki/Swanti_(festival))* festival by Buddhists. ## History The five-day long festival originated in the [Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent) and is likely a fusion of harvest festivals in ancient [India](/wiki/India). It is mentioned in early [Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit_literature) texts, such as the *[Padma Purana](/wiki/Padma_Purana)* and the *[Skanda Purana](/wiki/Skanda_Purana),* both of which were composed between the 7th and 10th centuries. The *diyas* (lamps) are mentioned in *Skanda Kishore Purana* as symbolising parts of the sun, describing it as the cosmic giver of light and energy to all life and which seasonally transitions in the Hindu calendar month of Kartik. Emperor [Harsha](/wiki/Harsha) refers to Deepavali, in the 7th-century Sanskrit play *[Nagananda](/wiki/Nagananda)*, as *Dīpapratipadotsava* (*dīpa* = light, *pratipadā* = first day, *utsava* = festival), where lamps were lit and newly engaged brides and grooms received gifts. [Rajasekhara](/wiki/Rajashekhara_(Sanskrit_poet)) referred to Deepavali as *Dipamalika* in his 9th-century *Kavyamimamsa*, wherein he mentions the tradition of homes being whitewashed and oil lamps decorated homes, streets, and markets in the night. Diwali was also described by numerous travellers from outside India. In his 11th-century memoir on India, the Persian traveller and historian [Al Biruni](/wiki/Ab%C5%AB_Ray%E1%B8%A5%C4%81n_al-B%C4%ABr%C5%ABn%C4%AB) wrote of Deepavali being celebrated by Hindus on the day of the New Moon in the month of Kartika. The Venetian merchant and traveller [Niccolò de' Conti](/wiki/Niccol%C3%B2_de%27_Conti) visited India in the early 15th century and wrote in his memoir, "on another of these festivals they fix up within their temples, and on the outside of the roofs, an innumerable number of oil lamps ... which are kept burning day and night" and that the families would gather, "clothe themselves in new garments", sing, dance, and feast. The 16th-century Portuguese traveller [Domingo Paes](/wiki/Domingo_Paes) wrote of his visit to the Hindu [Vijayanagara Empire](/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire), where *Dipavali* was celebrated in October with householders illuminating their homes, and their temples, with lamps. It is mentioned in the *[Ramayana](/wiki/Ramayana)* that Diwali was celebrated for only 2 years in [Ayodhya](/wiki/Ayodhya_(Ramayana)). Islamic historians of the [Delhi Sultanate](/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate) and the [Mughal Empire](/wiki/Mughal_Empire) era also mentioned Diwali and other Hindu festivals. A few, notably the [Mughal](/wiki/Mughal_Empire) emperor [Akbar](/wiki/Akbar), welcomed and participated in the festivities, whereas others banned such festivals as Diwali and [Holi](/wiki/Holi), as [Aurangzeb](/wiki/Aurangzeb) did in 1665.[g][h] Publications from the time of the [British Raj](/wiki/British_Raj) also made mention of Diwali, such as the note on Hindu festivals published in 1799 by [Sir William Jones](/wiki/William_Jones_(philologist)), a philologist known for his early observations on Sanskrit and [Indo-European languages](/wiki/Indo-European_languages). In his paper on *The Lunar Year of the Hindus*, Jones, then based in [Bengal](/wiki/Bengal), noted four of the five days of Diwali in the [autumn](/wiki/Autumn) months of *Aswina-Cartica* [*[sic](/wiki/Sic)*] as the following: *Bhutachaturdasi Yamaterpanam* (2nd day), *Lacshmipuja dipanwita* (the day of Diwali), *Dyuta pratipat Belipuja* (4th day), and *Bhratri dwitiya* (5th day). The *Lacshmipuja dipanwita*, remarked Jones, was a "great festival at night, in honour of Lakshmi, with illuminations on trees and houses".[i] ### Epigraphy Sanskrit inscriptions in stone and copper mentioning Diwali, occasionally alongside terms such as *Dipotsava*, *[Dipavali](/wiki/Dipawali_(Jainism))*, *Divali* and *Divalige*, have been discovered at numerous sites across India.[j] Examples include a 10th-century Rashtrakuta empire copper plate inscription of [Krishna III](/wiki/Krishna_III) (939–967 CE) that mentions *Dipotsava*, and a 12th-century mixed Sanskrit-Kannada Sinda inscription discovered in the Isvara temple of [Dharwad](/wiki/Dharwad) in Karnataka where the inscription refers to the festival as a "sacred occasion". According to [Lorenz Franz Kielhorn](/wiki/Lorenz_Franz_Kielhorn), a German Indologist known for translating many Indic inscriptions, this festival is mentioned as *Dipotsavam* in verses 6 and 7 of the Ranganatha temple Sanskrit inscription of the 13th-century [Venad](/wiki/Venad_(Kingdom)) Hindu king [Ravivarman Samgramadhira](/wiki/Ravivarman_Kula%C5%9B%C4%93khara). Part of the inscription, as translated by Kielhorn, reads: > the auspicious festival of lights which disperses the most profound darkness, which in former days was celebrated by the kings Ila, Kartavirya and Sagara, (...) as Sakra (Indra) is of the gods, the universal monarch who knows the duties by the three Vedas, afterwards celebrated here at Ranga for Vishnu, resplendent with Lakshmi resting on his radiant lap.[k] Jain inscriptions, such as the 10th-century Saundatti inscription about a donation of oil to Jinendra worship for the Diwali rituals, speak of *Dipotsava*. Another early 13th-century Sanskrit stone inscription, written in the Devanagari script, has been found in the north end of a mosque pillar in [Jalore](/wiki/Jalore), [Rajasthan](/wiki/Rajasthan) evidently built using materials from a demolished Jain temple. The inscription states that Ramachandracharya built and dedicated a drama performance hall, with a golden cupola, on Diwali.[l] ## Religious significance The religious significance of Diwali varies regionally within India. One tradition links the festival to legends in the Hindu epic *[Ramayana](/wiki/Ramayana)*, where Diwali is the day Rama, Sita, [Lakshmana](/wiki/Lakshman), and [Hanuman](/wiki/Hanuman) reached [Ayodhya](/wiki/Ayodhya_(Ramayana)) after a period of 14 years in exile after Rama's army of good, defeated demon king [Ravana](/wiki/Ravana)'s army of evil. Throughout the epic, Rama's decisions were always in line with *[dharma](/wiki/Dharma) (*duty*)* and the Diwali festival serves as a reminder for followers of Hinduism to maintain their dharma in day-to-day life. Per another popular tradition, in the [Dvapara Yuga](/wiki/Dvapara_Yuga) period, [Krishna](/wiki/Krishna), an [avatar](/wiki/Avatar) of [Vishnu](/wiki/Vishnu), killed the demon [Narakasura](/wiki/Narakasura), who was the evil king of [Pragjyotishapura](/wiki/Pragjyotishapura), near present-day Assam, and released 16000 girls held captive by Narakasura. Diwali was celebrated as a signifier of triumph of good over evil after Krishna's Victory over Narakasura. The day before Diwali is remembered as Naraka Chaturdashi, the day on which Narakasura was killed by Krishna. Many Hindus associate the festival with Goddess [Lakshmi](/wiki/Lakshmi), the goddess of wealth and prosperity, and wife of Vishnu. According to Pintchman, the start of the 5-day Diwali festival is stated in some popular contemporary sources as the day goddess Lakshmi was born from [Samudra Manthana](/wiki/Samudra_manthan), the churning of the cosmic ocean of milk by the [Devas](/wiki/Deva_(Hinduism)) (gods) and the [Asuras](/wiki/Asuras) (demons) – a Vedic legend that is also found in several [Puranas](/wiki/Puranas) such as the *[Padma Purana](/wiki/Padma_Purana)*, while the night of Diwali is when Lakshmi chose and wed Vishnu. Along with Lakshmi, who is representative of [Vaishnavism](/wiki/Vaishnavism), [Ganesha](/wiki/Ganesha), the elephant-headed son of [Parvati](/wiki/Parvati) and [Shiva](/wiki/Shiva) of [Shaivism](/wiki/Shaivism) tradition, is remembered as one who symbolises ethical beginnings and the remover of obstacles. Hindus of eastern India associate the festival with the Goddess Kali, who symbolises the victory of good over evil. Hindus from the Braj region in northern India, parts of [Assam](/wiki/Assam), as well as southern Tamil and Telugu communities view Diwali as the day the god Krishna overcame and destroyed the evil demon king Narakasura, in yet another symbolic victory of knowledge and good over ignorance and evil. Trade and merchant families and others also offer prayers to [Saraswati](/wiki/Saraswati), who embodies music, literature and learning and [Kubera](/wiki/Kubera), who symbolises book-keeping, treasury and wealth management. In western states such as Gujarat, and certain northern Hindu communities of India, the festival of Diwali signifies the start of a new year. Mythical tales shared on Diwali vary widely depending on region and even within Hindu tradition, yet all share a common focus on righteousness, self-inquiry and the importance of knowledge, which, according to Lindsey Harlan, an Indologist and scholar of Religious Studies, is the path to overcoming the "darkness of ignorance". The telling of these myths is reminiscent of the Hindu belief that good ultimately triumphs over evil. ### Other religions Originally a Hindu festival, Diwali has transcended religious lines. Diwali is celebrated by Hindus, Jains, Sikhs, and Newar Buddhists, although for each faith it marks different historical events and stories, but nonetheless the festival represents the same symbolic victory of light over darkness, knowledge over ignorance, and good over evil. #### Jainism In Jain religion, Diwali is celebrated in observance of "Mahavira Nirvana Divas", the physical death and final nirvana of [Mahavira](/wiki/Mahavira), the 24th [Tirthankar](/wiki/Tirthankar) of current time cycle. Nirvana is considered to be the state of a soul when it escapes from the cycle of birth and death, while experiencing its true nature of boundless bliss and infinite knowledge. The Jain Diwali celebrated in many parts of India has similar practices to the Hindu Diwali, such as the lighting of lamps. However, the focus of the Jain Diwali remains the dedication to Mahavira. According to the Jain tradition, this practice of lighting lamps first began on the day of Mahavira's nirvana in 527 BCE,[m] when 18 kings who had gathered for Mahavira's final teachings issued a proclamation that lamps be lit in remembrance of the "great light, Mahavira". This traditional belief of the origin of Diwali, and its significance to Jains, is reflected in their historic artworks such as paintings. #### Sikhism Sikhs celebrate Bandi Chhor Divas in remembrance of the release of [Guru Hargobind](/wiki/Guru_Hargobind) from the [Gwalior Fort](/wiki/Gwalior_Fort) prison by the Mughal emperor [Jahangir](/wiki/Jahangir) and the day he arrived at the Golden Temple in Amritsar. According to J.S. Grewal, a scholar of Sikhism and Sikh history, Diwali in the Sikh tradition is older than the sixth Guru Hargobind legend. [Guru Amar Das](/wiki/Guru_Amar_Das), the third Guru of the Sikhs, built a well in Goindwal with eighty-four steps and invited Sikhs to bathe in its [sacred waters](/wiki/Sacred_waters) on Baisakhi and Diwali as a form of community bonding. Over time, these spring and autumn festivals became the most important of Sikh festivals and holy sites such as Amritsar became focal points for annual pilgrimages. The festival of Diwali, according to Ray Colledge, highlights three events in Sikh history: the founding of the city of Amritsar in 1577, the release of Guru Hargobind from the Mughal prison, and the day of Bhai Mani Singh's martyrdom in 1738 as a result of his failure to pay a fine for trying to celebrate Diwali and thereafter refusing to convert to Islam.[n] #### Buddhism Diwali is not a festival for most Buddhists, with the exception of the [Newar](/wiki/Newar_people) people of Nepal who revere various deities in [Vajrayana](/wiki/Vajrayana) Buddhism and celebrate Diwali by offering prayers to Lakshmi. Newar Buddhists in Nepalese valleys also celebrate the Diwali festival over five days, in much the same way, and on the same days, as the Nepalese Hindu Diwali-Tihar festival. According to some observers, this traditional celebration by Newar Buddhists in Nepal, through the worship of Lakshmi and Vishnu during Diwali, is not [syncretism](/wiki/Syncretism) but rather a reflection of the freedom within [Mahayana](/wiki/Mahayana) Buddhist tradition to worship any deity for their worldly betterment. ## Celebrations
